Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research RAPID: Matriculation and Well-Being Under Emergent Events (MWEE): Using Data to Empower Campus Communities in Times of Crisis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Each of the nearly 20 million students that attended American colleges and universities in Fall 2019 had his or her education disrupted due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Colleges and universities responded quickly and dynamically to help mitigate disease spread while continuing to deliver a high-quality learning experience. Mitigation strategies involved rapid transitions to online learning, closure of on-campus housing with little to no notice, and drastic changes to student and university life over several weeks. The disruption has drastically changed our communities, and these changes may be particularly challenging for our most vulnerable students, including ones with housing and hunger insecurity or behavioral health issues. This RAPID project, Matriculation and Well-Being Under Emergent Events (MWEE), will utilize time-sensitive data associated with the COVID-19 pandemic to study student well-being. MWEE will focus on engineering students in undergraduate programs where a component of course success is often hands-on labs and teamwork. MWEE will harness data from five campuses, engage communities and encourage the development of processes and actions to address this global challenge. The institutions include a private university, a public university, and three land-grant universities, one of which is a historically black college and university (HBCU). Geographic regions include the South, Midwest and Pacific Northwest. <br/><br/>A better understanding of critical factors that influence the success of vulnerable students can provide insight for developing effective interventions for reducing college attrition associated with COVID-19. The knowledge can also potentially inform university decisions regarding response to other emergent events. MWEE aims to (i) collect and synthesize structured and unstructured data from multiple sources that relate to the health and behavior of students and (ii) utilize machine learning and optimization techniques to learn from the data to identify best practices, identify students at risk, and inform potential policies and interventions. The MWEE methodology will create a new convergent scientific paradigm to understand, assess, and measure individual and community well-being and resilience during complex and novel situations such as the COVID-19 pandemic. It is expected that universities will be able to layer the results with data from their campuses to predict retention and graduation rates given emergent events including COVID-19.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The COVID-19 pandemic has challenged our college and universities to respond quickly and dynamically to help mitigate disease spread. This has involved rapid transitions to online learning, closure of on-campus housing with little to no notice, and drastic changes to student and university life. This has radically  changed our communities in ways that may be particularly challenging for students with food and housing insecurity or behavioral health issues. The Matriculation and Well-Being Under Emergent Events (MWEE) project has studied the impact of COVID-19 university policies adopted to control disease spread on college students. It specifically considers a broad range of issues faced in emerging adulthood that contribute to disparities in well-being. In particular, MWEE collected ephemeral data associated with the COVID-19 pandemic to study its impact on student well-being.

For the nearly 20 million emerging adults (i.e., ages 18-29) in the US, college offers the opportunity to positively or negatively impact their life trajectories. Emerging adulthood is a critical developmental stage where people identify and commit to roles, relationships, and responsibilities of adulthood. Stressors such as hunger, homelessness, and behavioral health issues negatively impact belonging, graduation, employment, and financial stability. College students consistently seek support for anxiety, depression, and suicidality, with 56% and 45% facing housing and food insecurity, respectively. These stressors take a toll on student health, wealth and education outcomes well past the time a student drops out or graduates. The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated this stress, further exposing the disparities in college student well-being, and challenging colleges and universities to innovate.

This research has collected heterogeneous structured and unstructured longitudinal data including weekly student report of well-being over the course of the 2020-2021 and 2021-2022 academic years, student geolocation data, student performance data, and institutional policy information to map the psychological well-being dimensions to quantifiable metrics for assessing well-being dynamically and enable intelligent intervention. Well-being is multi-dimensional and has complex interactions across subjective and objective measures including mental, social, activities and functioning, physical, spiritual, emotional, intellectual, psychological, occupational, environmental and personal circumstance. The measurement and modeling of social and psychological constructs (e.g., identity, values, behavioral intention, etc.) driving health behavior and the processing of information about health is an active and open area of research: particularly with respect to efforts to validly and reliably measure well-being and other related constructs. It is necessary to create an engineered representation of social and behavioral responses to stimuli and interventions. Our collaborative grant, MWEE, has initiated this process. Existing studies have focused on shorter follow-up periods with a focus on predicting a change in well-being. These studies have not sought to model the evolution of student well-being. We extend this research to model the evolution of student well-being over the course of an academic semester. In addition, we have used the student performance data to model student academic well-being over the course of an academic program with the goal of understanding engineering student dropout. This longitudinal approach that makes predictions at key milestones through a student’s matriculation contributes to both the understanding of student well-being and methodologically to modeling the evolution of student performance.

As college students continue to struggle with the aftereffects of the COVID-19 pandemic including significant mental health challenges associated with adjusting to the trauma of the last several years, it is even more important to be able to use ephemeral data from this period to understand its impact on student well-being. Better understanding of key factors which influence the success of vulnerable students can provide insight for developing effective interventions for reducing college attrition associated with COVID-19 and potentially inform university decisions regarding response to extreme events such as the COVID-19 pandemic. Through this project, we identified differences in students’ self-report of anxiety and other well-being factors as a function of student movement during the night. The university and survey data can be mapped to psychological theory regarding well-being and can be used to estimate enrollment for the following year and to predict the “risk of a student dropping out” and the likelihood of graduation. For this project, we partnered with university Enrollment Management and Services management to better understand student dropout. Our analysis of the student performance data has been shared with the university leadership and has begun to inform how they think about student dropout and factors that may be used to mitigate it. This project has developed a framework for assessing student well-being over time and understanding these and other factors impact student performance in order to design effective early intervention strategies.

 


Last Modified: 12/12/2022
Modified by: Julie E Ivy
